desc.size: Medium-sized tree to 15 - 24 m tall, trunk diameter 30 cm - 0.6 m. Crown broadly rounded or occasionally flat-topped, with spreading, ascending branches.

part.partText: dark reddish brown, thick, shallowly furrowed into large, loose plates. Inner bark moist and slippery, especially when chewed.
rather stout, bright green becoming reddish brown, with short, gray hairs. Leaf scars half-round, covered with a corky layer, having 3 bundle scars.
dark brown to black, 4 - 6 mm long, nearly round, blunt, with rusty colored hairs, especially at the tip; flower buds conspicuous, spherical.

alternate, with stout, short, hairy leafstalks; green and very rough-hairy above, paler and hairy beneath; 10 - 17 cm long, half as wide, oval to elliptical, base asymmetrical, tip pointed, margins coarsely doubly-toothed, thick, firm, veins forked near the margin.
with both male and female reproductive organs (perfect); in drooping clusters, greenish, small, calyx bell-shaped.
single-seeded, winged (samara); in dense clusters; short-stalked, 2 cm long, oval, seed cavity brown and hairy, wings smooth, shallowly notched at the tip.

similarSpecies.comments: The rough, sandpaper-like texture and asymmetrical base of the leaves distinguishes Ulmus rubra from all others elms in the Chicago Region. The leaf veins of U. americana rarely fork, as does U. rubra, and its samaras have hairy margins. Ulmus procera has smaller leaves (5 - 8 cm long) and hairless samaras. Ulmus pumila also has smaller leaves (3 - 7 cm long), which are not distinctly asymmetrical at the base or doubly-toothed. Ulmus thomasii has corky wings on the twigs and leaves with a nearly symmetrical base. Characteristics of the hybrid U. x notha are intermediate of U. rubra and its other parent, U. pumila. The most distinctive features are the middle bud scales fringed with white hairs and the terminal scales fringed with reddish brown hairs. Celtis leaves, which are similar in appearance, have three main veins arising from the base of each blade.

speciesPage.flowering: Late March to late April, before the leaves.
speciesPage.habitatEcology: Frequent in woodlands, often along streams. Second-growth saplings are commonly seen along woodland borders. Has also been found growing in fens and other mesic sites.

notes.comments: The slippery inner bark of Ulmus rubra forms a moist mass when chewed, and was once used as a thirst quencher. The wood is used for furniture, boxes, crates, barrels, veneer farm implements, fence posts, and shipbuilding. This elm, as well as all native elm species, is susceptible to Dutch elm disease and phloem necrosis. See link to Dutch elm disease below.

etymology.comments: Ulmus is the Latin word for elm. Rubra means red, referring to the rust colored hairs on its buds.
